case_name: Union of India v. Ram Charan

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 1115 of 1962 is an appeal by special leave from judgments and orders dated February 16 and 26, 1960, of the Punjab High Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 1115 of 1962. Appeals by special leave from the judgments and orders dated February 16,26, 1960, of the Punjab High Court in Civil Misc. No. 1212-C of 1959 and Regular First Appeal No. 44 of 1955.

facts.text: Ram Charan obtained a decree for money against the Union of India on January 6, 1955.

anchor.surface_text: Ram Charan obtained a decree for money against the Unioun of India on January 6, 1955. The Union of India presented an appeal on April 6, 1955, in the High Court.

facts.text: Union of India presented an appeal on April 6, 1955, in the High Court.

anchor.surface_text: The Union of India presented an appeal on April 6, 1955, in the High Court. Ram Charan, the sole respondent, filed a cross- objection on July 31, 1955.

facts.text: Ram Charan filed a cross-objection on July 31, 1955.

anchor.surface_text: Ram Charan, the sole respondent, filed a cross- objection on July 31, 1955. On February 6, 1956 the High Court passed an order in companynection with the surety bond.

facts.text: On February 6, 1956 the High Court passed an order in connection with the surety bond. Ram Charan was represented.

anchor.surface_text: On February 6, 1956 the High Court passed an order in companynection with the surety bond. Ram Charan was represented at the proceedings.

facts.text: Ram Charan died on July 21, 1957.

anchor.surface_text: Ram Charan died on July 91, 1957. On March 18, 1958 an application was presented to the High Court on behalf of the appellant under O. XXII, r. 4, read with s. 151,

facts.text: On March 18, 1958 an application was presented to the High Court by Union of India under O. XXII r. 4 read with s. 151 CPC to bring legal representatives of Ram Charan on record.

anchor.surface_text: On March 18, 1958 an application was presented to the High Court on behalf of the appellant under O. XXII, r. 4, read with s. 151, Code of Civil Procedure, stating that Ram Charan died on July 21, 1937, that the Divisional Engineer, Telegraphs, Ambala Cantonment, learnt of his death on February 3, 1958,

facts.text: Application stated Divisional Engineer learnt of Ram Charan's death on February 3, 1958.

anchor.surface_text: stating that Ram Charan died on July 21, 1937, that the Divisional Engineer, Telegraphs, Ambala Cantonment, learnt of his death on February 3, 1958, and that the deceased had left as his legal representatives, an adopted son and a widow.

facts.text: Legal representatives named: adopted son and widow of Ram Charan.

anchor.surface_text: and that the deceased had left as his legal representatives, an adopted son and a widow. It was prayed that these legal representatives be brought on record in the place of the deceased respondent.

facts.text: On May 13, 1958, the widow of Ram Charan applied that she alone was the legal representative under a will and the adopted son was not.

anchor.surface_text: On May 13, 1958, the widow of Ram Charan applied that she alone was the legal representative of Ram Charan under a will and that the alleged adopted son was number the legal representative.

facts.text: Appellant's application for substitution heard on May 14, 1958, ordered to be heard at time of appeal hearing due to difference of opinion on limitation.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants application for bringing on record the legal representatives of the deceased Ram Charan came up for hearing on May 14, 1958. The Court ordered the application to be heard at the time of the hearing of the appeal as it was pointed out that there was a difference of opinion in the Court as to whether limitation under 0. XXII of the Code started from the date of death or from the date of knowledge of death.

facts.text: On February 16, 1960, High Court dismissed the substitution application holding Union failed to show sufficient cause.

anchor.surface_text: The application for substitution came up for decision on February 16, 1960. It was dismissed, the Court holding that the Union of India had failed to show that it was prevented from any sufficient cause from companytinuing the appeal.

facts.text: On February 26, 1960, the appeal was dismissed as having abated.

anchor.surface_text: On February 26, 1960, the appeal itself was dismissed as having abated.

facts.text: On May 14, 1960, application for leave to appeal to Supreme Court presented to High Court, rejected on May 17, 1960.

anchor.surface_text: On May 14, 1960, an application for leave to appeal to the Supreme Court was presented to the High Court. ... This application was rejected on May 17, 1960.

facts.text: Special leave granted by Supreme Court to appeal from High Court judgments dated February 16 and 26, 1960.

anchor.surface_text: Special leave was prayed for appealing from the judgment of the High Court of Punjab in R.F.A.No.44 of 1955 and C.M. No. 1212-C/59 dated February 16/26 of 1960. The order granting special leave said That special leave be and is hereby granted...

facts.text: Application dated March 17, 1958 filed under O. XXII rr. 4 and 9 read with s.151 CPC (as per High Court narration).

anchor.surface_text: It may be pointed out that in the narration of facts the High Court stated that the application dated March 17, 1958, was filed under O. XXII, rr. 4 and 9 read with s. 151 of the Code.

facts.text: High Court relied on Full Bench case Firm Dittu Ram Eyedan v. Om Press Co. Ltd.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court relied on the Full Bench case of its Court reported in Firm Dittu Ram Eyedan v. Om Press Co. Ltd.,  1 , which held that ignorance of the death of the defendant was number a sufficient cause...

facts.text: Union did not state it was not careless or vigilant regarding Ram Charan's whereabouts.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court held that the Union of India did number state either in its application dated March 17, 1958, or in the other application dated May 14, 1958, that the Government had number been careless in the matter and had been vigilant...

facts.text: Supreme Court rejected preliminary objection regarding special leave.

anchor.surface_text: A preliminary objection was taken... We do number see any force in this objection and reject it.

facts.text: High Court application for leave referred to both orders.

anchor.surface_text: The application for leave to appeal, though described as one against the judgment in the miscellaneous case and number against the order in the regular appeal, stated in paragraph I that the regular first appeal had been ordered to have abated...

facts.text: Ram Charan lived in Ambala Cantonment, to which place the appeal related.

anchor.surface_text: ...who lived in Ambala Cantonment, to which place the appeal related.

facts.text: Affidavit affirmed by Divisional Engineer true to his belief, not knowledge.

anchor.surface_text: The affidavit filed in support of this application did number companyvey any further information and it was solemnly affirmed by the dependent that the averments in the -affidavit were true to his belief The deponent was numberother than the Divisional Engineer...

facts.text: Supreme Court held mere ignorance of death not sufficient cause.

anchor.surface_text: We have shown above that the mere statement that the appellant was ignorant of the death of the respondent, cannot be sufficient...

facts.text: Limitation under Art. 171 Limitation Act is three months from death.

anchor.surface_text: The period of limitation prescribed for making such an application is three months, under Art. 171 of the First Schedule to the Limitation Act.

facts.text: Union took wrong attitude that limitation starts from knowledge of death.

anchor.surface_text: The most damaging thing for the appellant is that the application came up for bearing before the learned Single judge and at that time the stand taken by it was that limitation for such an application starts number from the date of death of the respondent but from the date of the appellants knowledge...

facts.text: Supreme Court upheld High Court's view on no sufficient cause.

anchor.surface_text: In these circumstances, the High Court cannot be said to have taken an erroneous view about the appellants number establishing sufficient ground...

issues.text: Whether special leave to appeal can be entertained by the Supreme Court without first moving the High Court for a certificate against the order dismissing the appeal as abated, in view of Order XIII Rule 2 of the Supreme Court Rules, 1950

anchor.surface_text: A preliminary objection was taken to the effect that the appellant having not applied to the High Court for leave to appeal against the order dated February 26, 1960 in Regular First Appeal, that order had become final and special leave could not be asked for from this Court in view of Order XIII, r.2 of the Supreme Court Rules, 1950, the rule being Where an appeal lies to the Supreme Court on a certificate issued by the High Court or other tribunal, no application to the Supreme Court for special leave to appeal shall be entertained unless the High Court

issues.text: Whether mere ignorance of the death of the respondent constitutes sufficient cause under Order XXII Rule 9 CPC for failure to apply for substitution of legal representatives within time

anchor.surface_text: The contentions raised for the appellant in this Court are That mere ignorance of death of the respondent was sufficient cause for the appellants inability to apply for the impleading of the legal representatives within time, unless it be that the appellant was guilty of some negligence or some act or omission which led to the delay in his making the application. Once the respondent is served in the first appeal, no duty is cast on the appellant to make regular enquiries about the state of health of the respondent.

issues.text: Whether the period of limitation under Order XXII for application to substitute legal representatives starts from the date of death or from the date of knowledge of death

anchor.surface_text: The Court ordered the application to be heard at the time of the hearing of the appeal as it was pointed out that there was a difference of opinion in the Court as to whether limitation under 0. XXII of the Code started from the date of death or from the date of knowledge of death. Subsequently, on an application on behalf of the legal representatives, it was ordered that the question of abatement be decided first and thereafter the printing of the record be taken on hand.

issues.text: Whether the court can invoke inherent powers under Section 151 CPC to implead legal representatives after abatement of the appeal

anchor.surface_text: We may say at once that there is no force in the fourth point. The Court is not to invoke its inherent powers under s. 151, C.P.C. for the purposes of impleading the legal representatives of a deceased respondent, if the suit had abated on account of the appellant not taking appropriate steps within time to bring the legal representatives of the deceased party on the record and when its application for setting aside the abatement is not allowed on account of its failure to satisfy the Court that there was sufficient cause

issues.text: Whether the appellant established sufficient cause on facts to set aside the abatement, including absence of negligence and reasons for delayed knowledge of death

anchor.surface_text: It was dismissed, the Court holding that the Union of India had failed to show that it was prevented from any sufficient cause from continuing the appeal. On February 26, 1960, the appeal itself was dismissed as having abated. On May 14, 1960, an application for leave to appeal to the Supreme Court was presented to the High Court.

Ltd.,  1 , which held that ignorance of the death of the defendant was number a sufficient cause for setting aside the abatement when an application to bring the legal representatives of the deceased on the record was made after the expiry of the period of limitation, as the law imposed an obligation on the person applying for bringing the legal representatives of the deceased on the record and he had, therefore, to show absence of want of care.

holdings.text: The preliminary objection to the maintainability of the special leave petition is rejected as the application for leave to the High Court covered both the substitution order and the abatement order.

anchor.surface_text: We do number see any force in this objection and reject it. The application for leave to appeal, though described as one against the judgment in the miscellaneous case and number against the order in the regular appeal, stated in paragraph I that the regular first appeal had been ordered to have abated and in paragraph 3 that it was a fit case in which necessary certificate for filing an appeal against the judgment passed by the Court in regular first appeal No. 44 of 1955 be granted. Both these statements refer to the proceedings in companynection with the regular first appeal and number of the order on the miscellaneous application for substitution.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Application for certificate referred to both orders explicitly in paras 1 and 3, and High Court construed it as such; thus Order XIII r.2 SC Rules not attracted.

holdings.text: The Court cannot invoke inherent powers under s.151 CPC to implead legal representatives after abatement if no sufficient cause shown to set aside abatement under O.XXII r.9.

anchor.surface_text: We may say at once that there is numberforce in the fourth point. The Court is number to invoke its inherent powers under s. 151, C.P.C. for the purposes of impleading the legal representatives of a deceased respondent, if the suit had abated on account of the appellant number taking appropriate steps within time to bring the legal representatives of the deceased party on the record and when its application for setting aside the abatement is number allowed on account of its failure to satisfy the Court that there was sufficient cause

holdings.reasoning_summary: Inherent powers cannot override mandatory procedure under O.XXII for substitution and abatement; abatement vests rights in opposite party.

holdings.text: Limitation period under Art.171 Limitation Act for substitution application under O.XXII r.4 is three months from date of death, not from date of knowledge of death.

anchor.surface_text: The period of limitation prescribed for making such an application is three months, under Art. 171 of the First Schedule to the Limitation Act. ... The limitation for an application to set aside abatement of a suit does start on the death of the deceased respondent. Article 171, First Schedule to the Limitation Act provides that. It does number provide the limitation to start from the date of the appellants knowledge thereof.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Explicit textual reading of Art.171; legislature fixed 3 months expecting knowledge within period, with s.5 for condonation; appellant's contrary stand unjustified.

holdings.text: Mere ignorance or belated knowledge of death does not constitute sufficient cause under O.XXII r.9 to set aside abatement; applicant must prove reasons for ignorance, absence of negligence, and diligence.

anchor.surface_text: We have shown above that the mere statement that the appellant was ignorant of the death of the respondent, cannot be sufficient... Rule 9 of O. XXII of the Code requires the plaintiff to prove that he was prevented by any sufficient cause from companytinuing the suit. The mere allegation about his number companying to know of the death of the opposite party is number sufficient. He had to state reasons which, according to him, led to his number knowing of the death of the defendant within reasonable time and to establish those reasons to the satisfaction of the Court

holdings.reasoning_summary: O.XXII r.9 requires proof of sufficient cause preventing timely application; bare ignorance insufficient as legislature provided time and s.5; court must scrutinize evidence; aligns with Full Bench precedent.

holdings.text: Appellant failed to establish sufficient cause for delay in substitution application; High Court correctly dismissed it and appeal abated.
holdings.reasoning_summary: No reasons given for delayed knowledge despite local connection; affidavit on belief not knowledge; wrong legal stand on limitation; no vigilance shown; bare statements inadequate.

anchor.surface_text: The period of limitation prescribed for making such an application is three months, under Art. 171 of the First Schedule to the Limitation Act. ... The limitation for an application to set aside abatement of a suit does start on the death of the deceased respondent. Article 171, First Schedule to the Limitation Act provides that. It does number provide the limitation to start from the date of the appellants knowledge thereof.

He had to state reasons which, according to him, led to his number knowing of the death of the defendant within reasonable time and to establish those reasons to the satisfaction of the Court
